span.span:
This message pertains to our school families that have students in grades 3 -12 and indicated that they do not have a device to use for online learning through our technology surveys.
On Thursday, April 2, the delivery of Chromebooks will begin. For families that participate in the free meal program and have the food delivered to a bus stop, they will receive their Chromebook at the same time as the food delivery. For all other families, Chromebooks will be delivered by various CW staff members throughout the day on Thursday.
The coordination of devices for students in grades 3 – 12 has been a very complicated process. Although we feel very confident that we’ve accounted for all devices needed, with an undertaking of this size, there may be an oversight. Please feel free to let us know if you indicated that you need a device and did not receive one on Thursday.
As always, we appreciate the understanding and patience of all our school families as we transition to distance learning. Our community can be incredibly proud of all the hard work our school staff has put into the food service program as well as the conversion to distance learning!

p.span: Please find two critical updates for our school families regarding school operations and programming.

First, many of you may have already seen the latest "Safer at Home" Executive Order put out by Governor Evers regarding the COVID-19 virus. If not, the order is linked HERE. After reading the order, naturally, many of our school families and staff have questions relating to how this newest order may affect school operations. After consultation with several entities, they've assured us that while schools will remain closed, many of the services we are currently doing can stay in place. Rest assured that while practicing all precautionary measures advised, CWASD will continue to support our students with the meal program as well as pursuing our path towards instruction.

Second, since we are still able to provide educational programming, all families of students in grades 6 - 12 will find a link to our technology assessment posted to Student Access, Family Access as well as sent to email accounts. If you have a student(s) in grades 6 - 12 and did not receive the link for the survey, you may click HERE. For us to successfully deploy any e-learning opportunities for our students, it is critical for us to know the needs of our school families. Please be sure to complete the survey no later than noon on Friday, March 27. Thank you for your time and efforts!

li.span: As a reminder to our school families, CWASD will be providing educational and support services to our students during the mandatory closure time period. We appreciate the patience and understanding that our school families have shown during this development period. Our teaching staff, support staff, and administrators are currently developing a combination of online learning opportunities (grades 3-12) as well as take-home learning opportunities (grades PreK - 2). This is an extremely difficult endeavor but they are doing an excellent job preparing for our students. The expectation is for all students to be engaged in formal learning opportunities no later than Monday, April 6.

Today, CWASD began its first week of the free meal program for our school families. Between breakfast and lunch, over 400 meals were prepared and provided to our school families. Our school staff that made that happen deserve an immense amount of gratitude for their efforts. It was a pleasure to see how hard they worked to make this happen for our students.
Also, we want to thank John Erb and Erb Rural Bus Service for providing drivers and the buses to deliver the meals to our school families. This is truly a group effort and it is a pleasure to see people come together to help others.
If any school family experienced any problems related to the meal program, please feel free to contact either:

p.span: Sandy Stevens at (715)924-2226 ext. 2057; sstevens@cwasd.k12.wi.us
OR
Tammy Lenbom at (715) 924-2226 ext. 2019; tlenbom@cwasd.k12.wi.us

li.span: In an attempt to keep our families updated, please find the direct links to the HS/MS and Roselawn family update pages below:

p.span: Good morning CW Families:

As many of you are aware, late yesterday afternoon, Governor Evers issued a follow-up executive order regarding many topics including revising the school closure time period. As of the press release, schools will be closed for an indefinite period of time for the duration of the public health emergency. As a result, we are planning for longer-term closing than the April 3 date sent out last week. We are advising that our school families also plan ahead in the event of a longer-term closing of the schools.
Please know that our staff is working hard to develop instruction and content that can be delivered in a distance-learning model. This is not an easy process and we want it replicate (as closely as possible) what our students receive as if they were in the classrooms. Instead of rushing to push out a substandard product, we prefer to take the necessary time and steps to develop the best experience possible. We appreciate our school families' patience and understanding as we convert our current model into a distance learning format. In the meantime, please feel free to have your students engage in the many resources we've provided in yesterday's post.

In addition, we want our school families to be aware that CWASD is currently developing ways that we can continue to provide nonacademic services such as mental health therapy, counseling, special education services, etc.
Click here to read the PRESS RELEASE.
We wanted to take a moment to update everyone on plans for the coming days. The situation is fluid and can change quickly, but we will do our best to update you as we are able.

span.span: Currently, CW classes have been canceled until April 6. This includes ALL school-related activities (rehearsals, athletic practices, etc.). The buildings themselves are also closed to the general public. The Chetek Kids Club has halted operations for the time being as well.
Students may come into the buildings on Wednesday, March 18, from 7-9 a.m. and 3-5 p.m., so individuals can pick up any items they may need.

p.span: Public events, such as the Middle School Memorial Concert, the Variety Show, athletic events, and the Drama Club’s upcoming production have been postponed indefinitely. Details on those will follow when we have them set. This includes the 4K screening as well; we are in the process of rescheduling and communicating with families regarding their screening appointments.

span.span: While the current school closure is effective through April 6, 2020, there is the possibility that the closure could be extended beyond that. We want parents and guardians to begin thinking about this in the event that schools in Wisconsin do remain closed. We, too, are looking at options if this should happen and will communicate those if need be.

We are working on creating a safe and responsible option to provide meals to students in our community. You can learn more about the program from Dr. Johnson’s letter here. If you are interested in your child receiving meals, please fill out this survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/VYV8QH8

p.b: Mandatory Instructional Hours and Make-Up Days

span.span: We know many students and parents may have questions about mandatory contact hours and make-up days. The Department of Public Instruction (DPI) has indicated they will waive the hour requirement for any school district that requests the DPI to do so due to this ongoing public health emergency. CWASD intends to fully apply for this waiver to adhere with the current school calendar, eliminating the need for classes to continue into June.

During this interim period that our teaching staff is working to develop alternative ways to continue educating our students, we know parents and families are looking for online and alternative options to help continue stimulating students’ brains while away from the classroom.
There are many educational resources out there. You can find a very thorough list here. The School Library Journal also has a nice overview of some services being offered as well. In addition, there are several museums and galleries that provide virtual tours and online exhibits. You can check out some of those here.

p.span: Please know that our teaching staff will be reaching out to our students and school families to check on them and to offer any additional options for learning during this school closure time.

a.span: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention-Coronavirus Disease Information

span.span: If you have specific questions regarding COVID-19, we suggest that you visit the Center for Disease Control’s website here. They have wonderful information and resources that may answer many specific questions, including recommendations for steps you can take to protect yourself and help minimize the spread of the virus. More locally, you can also check out the WI Dept. of Health Services or get updates for the county with Barron County Public Health.
We continue to ask that you visit our website for additional information. We will update things there as necessary.

We know things are actively changing on a daily, even hourly basis, so we thank you for your patience as we move forward. Know that we will get through this together. As always, please don’t hesitate to contact us with any questions.

p.span: At CWASD, the health, safety and well-being of our students and staff are our top priorities. With the recently elevated discussion regarding the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the news, we want to take a moment to reinforce preventive safety measures and reference our process and communications. We are also well aware that the situation is fluid and can change at any moment. As such, should anything change with school operations, events and activities, we will update this page with that information.

First, it is important to remember that at this time, there have only been a small number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in the United States. As a school district, we are closely monitoring the situation and taking guidance from the Wisconsin Department of Health and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

span.strong: UPDATE: Governor Evers has ordered all schools to close beginning Wednesday, March 18 until April 6. CWASD has elected to begin closure Monday, March 16. We are also asking that staff remain home until further notice as well. Should any of this change, we'll notify families as soon as we are able.

p.span: We encourage our students, staff and families to be mindful of key preventive measures. The CDC offers some tips on its website that can be useful in avoiding the spread of this and other illnesses.
We all play a role in reducing the likelihood of a coronovirus outbreak in our school district community. We encourage everyone to practice good habits, including:

li.span: Wash your hands regularly, especially after using the restroom and before preparing or consuming food. Using soap and hot water, wash for about 20 seconds. Be sure to also wash your fingertips.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw away the tissue. If you don't have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them at home from school. Allow them some time to feel better so that they do not risk infecting others. Keeping children home when they are sick is critical to prevention.

p.span: We've used our spring break as an opportunity to do a deep clean of our buildings, including using electrostatic cleaners, power cleaners, and disinfecting surfaces. We will implement a regular disinfecting routine once the students return from break. We’ve made sure to stock up on cleaning supplies including disinfecting wipes, cleaners, soaps and hand sanitizer. We will continue to be in close communication to what the health experts recommend and will implement their recommendations accordingly.

At this time Barron County has no cases of COVID19 (2019 Novel Coronavirus). We know that there are a lot of questions and concerns around this illness. Information is changing quickly and we will update you as needed. Please continue to monitor credible information sources such as cdc.gov or dhs.wisconsin.gov for the most up to date information.

Public Health and Barron County medical systems are working together on this situation. Anyone at medium to high risk (travel to a high risk area, close contact with a suspected case, or being tested) are contacted and interviewed by public health and advised on next steps.

The Barron County Health and Human Services Department continues to work to prevent cases and prepare our community on how to slow the spread if it does come to Barron County. As a community partner your help is needed. While the CDC expects 80% of cases to be mild to moderate and in no need for medical care, 20% of cases are expected to be severe. Those at highest risk for severe illness are the elderly and those with other chronic illness. Slowing the spread will help protect our community and ensure our medical systems do not become overwhelmed.
If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.
Here are some additional resources:
